You are missing the fact that India does have massive liabilities denominated in foreign currency, oil. India has to import oil. If they want to import oil they have to exchange goods and services for it. They can't simply print new rupees and expect to maintain a fixed exchange rate for oil just as other countries can't expect to print currency and exchange them at a fixed rate for dollars in order to pay back dollar denominated debt.

The problem in India is that they built an economy based on cheap energy and cheap credit. India has to import oil. As a result they have to produce something that they can trade to the outside world in exchange for oil. The Indian government has been using cheap credit (QE) to extend oil subsidies to importers to artificially depress the cost of oil in the economy and thereby make their products more competitive. Now that the cost of capital is rising, they can no longer afford those subsidies. The new measures to provide dollar loans to oil importers will just make the situation worse. The RBI is taking dollar savings, giving them to oil companies to buy oil from the global market, taking that oil and running it through the Indian economy to produce products that no one in the world actually wants. As it stands now the Indian economy produces goods from commodities they buy from the global market that are worth less than the sum of their parts (oil+commodities+labor<goods made in China/Germany/Japan/USA).

I tend to agree with Mr. Duda. My knowledge of any potential candidate, Mr. Summers and Ms. Yellen, is far too limited to make any informed judgment.

Clearly Mr. Summers is not a particularly well-socialized person. He clearly has made major mistakes as a public figure, but the repeated bashing of him by many commenters here and elsewhere seems overblown to me.

I doubt that he would be in anyone's pocket. I even suspect that he might confer with competent individuals such as Mr. Krugman and many others of similar capability in determining the best policies to pursue. I also suspect that he would rip to shreds without much effort the nitwit Republicans in future USA Congresses where he is attacked by them for doing one thing or another. Lack of socialization has its advantages at times.

Regarding Mr. Obama's decision-making, it seems to me that he is trying to do the best that he can. Far better than the pathetic "best that he or she can" from alternative possible USA presidents.

I read and saw love for their children and for Caroline. Their actions confirm their deep love. Like all people, when confronted with a challenge, one is often in denial before getting to acceptance and then gratitude. I believe their comments were very honest and realistic and is something we all need to hear so that other couples dealing with these and other issues know that there is light at the end of the tunnel and that it is normal to have feelings that you often cannot justify or understand but that at the end of the day, you need to get to acceptance and to do your best. I find this couple very inspirational. They are good people with no BS.

I didn't hear resentment, just honesty about their struggle to help their daughter. Keep in mind that this was a different time. Attitudes toward people with disabilities have progressed a lot since then. As the couple said, many families used to place children with disabilities in institutions and give up on them. They instead did everything possible to help Caroline. They strike me as extraordinarily caring and good people.

I know the Cokers, and can attest that they have a vivid and powerful relationship, fully engaged and fully appreciating each other.  Caroline is a bright woman in many ways -- years ago, I drove up in a rental car, and she approached me with suspicion.  "I thought you told me you're from New York," she said.  When I said I was, she replied "then how come you're driving a car from Florida?"

This is a wonderful series. It is great to read stories that don't minimize or trivialize the issues that couples face but show how people can work through them. There are indeed huge numbers of "success" stories to go with all the sad news.

I agree that these columns are pretty useless. However, that might be because there are really no good answers to many of these questions. A more honest response than all the platitudes might be "I don't have a good answer, but here are a few things that sometimes work for some people - Godspeed and/or good luck."

I am also tired of the pious platitude that addiction is just like any other illness and we shouldn't blame the addict - After all, the truism goes, we don't blame the diabetic, etc. I'm sorry to inform you but a diabetic doesn't end up on the street after losing their house and their children and stealing from their family. If I sound bitter, I am - somewhere in my (upper-middle class, highly educated, brilliant Boomer) ex-husband's meth-fueled life, he knew what he was doing and at some point, he stopped doing it, with no help, as far as I can tell from anyone else. There were no residential facilities that would take him - addiction treatment centers usually won't take someone in the throes of meth-induced psychosis (believe me, I tried); such a person won't go into detox voluntarily; and involuntary mental health holds don't last long enough to achieve anything (believe me, I tried that too). He finally went to county jail on some public nuisance misdemeanor and couldn't get bail and detoxed there - By God's grace or good luck, one of those times he stopped. Welcome to drug treatment in America.

Actually, you all know that we don't really know where Asperger's comes from. NIH, as well as other reputable sources says as much.

http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/asperger-syndrome

According to them, it "appears likely that a combination of genetic variations and environmental factors influence the development of this complex condition." We know it may be genetic, but no gene has been isolated. NIH states that it is "a difference in brain development". Brain development, as you know, is effected by many factors, including prenatal care (environmental/nutritional). It is not the sole cause of AS, and may not be so for many AS, but it can be a major factor in certain cases. It also is common sense. If a mother is young, has no prenatal care, etc. the (brain) development of the child is at risk. This is cutting edge research from reputable sources, including major research hospitals in NYC.

I wish commenters were less judgmental, esp. in an emotional topic such as adoption, AS, etc.

Cool idea, but the quasi-analyticity is pretty quasi. One issue with the mechanics of integrals is that if you integrate over a closed curve, your answer shouldn't depend on where you start. But in this problem, that will matter: the change given by N E S W is different than S W N E. Whether it's possible to factor that in somehow (maybe keep track of the disparity between N and S?) is a neat thought. It would be cool if you could translate information about, say, the area of the shape defined by a closed loop (thinking of the blocks themselves as discontinuities), along with one other factor and get an answer out of this. I'll have to play with the idea.

Thanks again for another great response. It’s been fantastic to see the solutions, new questions, and sheer elbow grease people put into the Pilgrim’s Puzzle.

First off, thanks to Gary for the tool at http://www.garyhewitt.net/nyt/pilgrim.html. You can use it to check that any of the following solutions work.

Some people solved the puzzle by noticing that by walking certain loops, it’s possible to adjust the tax the Pilgrim has to pay, which can be very helpful. As Steve Kass pointed out, “One useful realization was that traversing a tight square by moving S,E,N,W (when there's room) is a way to gain one silver piece, regardless of where you are or how much you owe or are owed.”

Rob used a similar method to produce two solutions that had repeated paths.

Rob’s second solution: “S, S, S, S, then circles the Southwest block four times (resulting in -8), then move E, E, E, E, arriving with 0 debt.”

The shortest such path is 12 blocks long. Ravi gave this solution:
S E N W S S S E E E E S
which has the lovely property of creating a -1 at the starting point rather than a 0, which makes for a much easier beginning.

For those who tackled the nonrepeating version, one approach was to create at least one larger loop. The shortest possible path is 14 roads long, but it is not unique. Readers gave quite a few. These four are from Gary, Tom Enrico, and Ravi:

S,S,S,E,E,E,N,N,W,S,S,S,E,E
S,S,E,E,E,N,N,W,S,S,S,E,E,S 
S,S,E,E,E,N,W,W,S,S,E,S,E,E 
S,E,E,E,N,W,W,S,S,E,S,E,E,S

The longest nonrepeating path we saw was

Here’s one of length 20 from Golden Dragon:
S, E, E, E, S, E, N, W, N, W, S, S, W, W, S, S, E, E, E, E

Gary gave us this snaking path of length 22, which is the reigning champion for longest solution, and has the distinction of being the only solution to begin with E:
E, S, E, E, S, W, W, S, E, E, E, N, N, N, W, W, S, S, S, S, E, E 
I found that it’s also possible to begin with E, E:
E, E, S, S, S, E, E, N, N, N, W, S, W, W, W, S, S, S, E, E, E, E.

At some point, there’s a fair amount of trial and error here. Let’s at least see if we can prove something about the shortest possible solution.

Statement. The shortest path with repetition is length 12.

Proof. The shortest path from NW to SE corner is length 8. In order to be at 0 in column 5, the Pilgrim must be at -2 in column 4, so a negative tax is necessary. If the Pilgrim only took steps to S and E, then she would be at 2 or greater the moment she left the Western side of Duona. This means that minimally, two W or one N (to drop the number below 2) followed by one W are necessary to drop below 0. Each W or N actually adds a total of length two to the total length, since they must be “unwalked” with an E or a S at some point in the future. Hence, the shortest path is length 12.
Incidentally, 2 Ws is an impossible option in a length 12 solution, since the 2 Es required to allow them to be walked would effectively undue their effect without a N.
